SENT.plain: A 35-year-old male was admitted with headache, nausea, and vomiting persisting for 2 days
Computed tomography (CT) revealed a left chronic subdural hematoma
Cerebral angiography demonstrated cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST)

He had presented with a subcutaneous mass involving the neck at age 2 years, which was shown to be a cavernous angioma, and thereafter shown signs of consumptive coagulopathy with systemic multiple hemangiomas
Burr hole aspiration of the hematoma was performed
Seventy-two-hours later, he developed clouding of consciousness and right hemiparesis
CT revealed a fresh hematoma in the operated subdural cavity and hemorrhagic diathesis manifested
A frontotemporoparietal large craniotomy was performed to remove the hematoma
He had a satisfactory postoperative course
Collateral venous pathways, resulting from the CVST due to systemic multiple hemangiomas, may have caused hemodynamic stress in the bridging veins which subsequently induced chronic subdural hematoma
